> [musickiller](#comment_33_15NScazvsCHNmiXi6o6nvaMiwjeJYizgZQ): how can one block torrents? o_O Stupid Russian politicians block torrent sites too, but it's not a problem for Tor..
> And I speak of DHT, not trackers!

There is many ways to do this: packet inspection/udp restrict/port whitelist/router.bittorrent.com (central DHT server for most of torrent clients)  connection
Blocking a standard, https connection is much harder, than detecting a P2P one. 

If someone wants to block Tor, then its also easy, since all Tor node ip is public: https://torstatus.blutmagie.de/

> [musickiller](#comment_34_15NScazvsCHNmiXi6o6nvaMiwjeJYizgZQ): I thought, ZeroNet is also p2p o_O

it's also possible to detect zeronet p2p traffic, but since it's a new and not well known protocol probably you can still use zeronet on networks where bittorrent is blocked.
The hub feature is required because technical reasons, but like i also written there: _if you don't want to trust the hub owner, then you can create your own hub_

> [redacted](#comment_6_1QQggeZo72jptq7AvVQbrQKXZetKzF5kj): @nofish Oh, you're right. Is it the ZeroNet frame doing the conversion or ZeroBlog? Either way, kind of hacky.

It's done by the site, and this is the correct, official format. using relative urls for cross-site linking even more hacky and bad idea.

The main problem with relative urls: it's not future proof and compatible with direct domains (http://127.0.0.1:43110/ less)
If you type `<a href="/zerotalk.bit ">` the browser does not able to know if you want to access the site zerotalk.bit or http://yourblog.bit/zerotalk.bit, so please never use that format. + It's not working outside of zeronet and because of that unique string is also a bad idea. (eg. http://127.0.0.1:43110/siteaddress also works on twitter if we add a custom http://zero/seaddress, then its not.)
